Jonathan metel I'm associate professor
of Psychiatry and women's studies and
director of the program in culture
health and medicine at the University of
Michigan so basically I have a split
appointment at the University of
Michigan the majority of my time is
spent teaching graduate and
undergraduate courses on the history of
Psych Psychiatry the history of medicine
and also on gender and race politics in
the United States I also work as a
psychiatrist at the University so I also
uh am an attending psychiatrist in the
outpatient Psychiatry clinic and I work
in the psychiatric emergency room in
other other uh treatment
sites in terms of present day Psychiatry
I mean as you mentioned there have been
changes with every new version of the
DSM the diagnostic and statistic IAL
manual that have come out that have
sharpened our understanding of what
schizophrenia is and so in the present
day we think of schizophrenia as an
illness that yeah the main symptoms are
delusions hallucinations mostly hearing
voices sometimes seeing things kind of
losing touch with reality also paranoia
feeling like people are out to get you
um and social withdrawal what are called
negative symptoms cognitive cognitive
withdrawal social withdrawal so it's a
very very debil debilitating very
serious mental illness but as you
mentioned this definition has changed
over time and it's also changed in
relation to changing popular perceptions
about how people with schizophrenia
act sure so in my book that's in part
the story I tell is how changing
psychiatric definitions of schizophrenia
and changing American cultural
definitions of schizophrenia really have
morphed in to each other over time and
particularly in relation to histories
about race in the United States so one
of the central narratives of the book is
that in particularly the early 1920s
1930s 1940s when the idea of
schizophrenia itself was first coming to
the United States from Europe there was
a general assumption that persons who
suffered from schizophrenia were either
shy or calm or they were Geniuses it was
often represented as an illness that
Afflicted white novelists or poets and
as I say these these were very often in
popular and psychiatric represent
representation assumed to be white
people now this was a you know kind of a
a gross generalization but in part what
was happening was that the illness
itself was defined almost as a
personality disorder like a split
personality so it was taken up by
psychoanalysts used in psychoanalytic
sessions and popular representation
really picked that up um two instances
from this time period that I think are
very important one is a film that came
out in 1948 called the snake pit uh
which was an Olivia deavin movie from uh
made from a book several years earlier
of the same name and it really showed
schizophrenia as being an illness that
Afflicted a white a particular white
middle class uh woman um also when early
versions of the diagnostic manual came
out in the early
1950s it really was it was called at
that time schizophrenic reaction and was
assumed to be mostly a personality a
personality condition all of a sudden in
the 1960s American
culture newspapers magazines movies
start to represent angry
African-American men as in part being uh
inflicted with a new form of this
particular illness so in the book I show
some drug ads for example that actually
show pictures of urban riots and race
riots in the streets uh and talk about
um how really the illness assumptions
about the illness change and the other
key thing that happens in the 1960s is
that the official psychiatric definition
changes all of a sudden in
1968 the second version of the
diagnostic manual comes out and there's
new language that says aggression
hostility projection this is all added
to the definition of paranoid
schizophrenia and what I show is that
those terms were preferentially used not
only to talk about these new kinds of
patients African-American men but also
to change our ideas about how violent
people with schizophrenia are how
hostile they were how they might act
which led to a lot of
fear even the people who we might think
of as being problematic in a way doctors
who were at that point overdiagnosing
schizophrenia and African-American men I
found so I mean the drug ads I would say
are and I invite people to look at the
images there they in the book um they're
exp I mean I don't know what the people
were thinking at the time but they were
just problematically racist and I think
it's hard not to look at those ads and
and see that anything else um but in
general I think that many of the doctors
and the sources that I look at were
actually trying to help people they
using the new state-of-the-art
diagnostic criteria that were coming
from their profession and I found
relatively few examples of people
actually trying to hurt people what they
were saying was oh here's a new
definition of illness that we can apply
to people and I think a lot of the
changes were happening as you suggest at
a much bigger level institutional levels
structural levels the level of the kind
of cultural unconscious in a way that
was shifting how we thought about these
people so you know a few examples from
the hospital I looked at um I tell the
story of different groups of patients
through through the book uh project um
and some of the key people I talk about
were African-American men and let me
just back up first and say that this was
a hospital the Ionia state hospital for
the criminally
insane that uh is or or was about 3
hours north of Detroit uh and it it's
kind of a central part of the story
story I tell because in the 1920s 30s
40s 50s the census listed the majority
of patients in the hospital as being
members of a category called us white um
and most of the patients were from the
rural Midwest about 30% of the hospital
were women um and there were assumptions
that these patients were especially
patients with schizophrenia were not
particularly violent so they would take
these people out on field trips um bring
them to the state fair have them go and
interact with the
community all of a sudden in the 1950s
and really the 1960s you see increasing
numbers of African-American men brought
to the hospital from Detroit for various
reasons some had committed crimes some
had participated in civil rights
protests some had been uh participants
in urban riots at the time they all
passed through various forms of of the
penal system and ended up diagnosed with
schizophrenia and locked into
psychiatric Wards and so it's it was a
very complicated question for me how did
these men end up diagnosed with
schizophrenia was it because of some
inherent illness was it because of their
participation in anti-government
protests was it because they had been
abused in the prison system I found
evidence for all three of those
narratives but what was interesting was
the earlier people people the women who
had been diagnosed with schizophrenia
were all rediagnosis
sitution isation movement but many of
the men who had been part of these
protests actually ended up staying in
even as the hospital itself changed into
something where security was much more
of an issue and you see the hospital
itself develop more and more fences
barbed wire remotes and actually at the
end of the story I tell the hospital
itself becomes a prison in
1977 and functioned for about the next
three decades as a medium security
prison so it really was this
transformation not just in assumptions
about
schizophrenia but about how we think
about people with schizophrenia as being
um initially kind of docile and harmless
to being threats and in fact threats
that needed to be in prisons in addition
to psychiatric hospitals
basically the the central argument of
the book is that there was a
transformation in popular and medical
and psychiatric understandings of
schizophrenia that happened in the
1960s in relation to uh certain
responses different kinds of responses
to the Civil Rights era and to the
tensions of the Civil Rights Movement at
the time and I show pretty pretty
directly how civil rights politics civil
rights anxieties other kinds of
things really shaped our understanding
of of insanity in this country um and
one part of that narrative is that as I
was mentioning before we uh we developed
at that time an A belief that
schizophrenia was an illness that was
increasingly marked by anger hostility
projection and even though that's not
part of the diagnosis anymore you see
the origin in the 1960s
of a set of stigmatizations of people
with with schizophrenia in particular as
being violent that Rose throughout the
latter half of the 20th century even
after they were associated with race all
of a sudden this initially this was a
category that was applied to these angry
protesting African-American men but you
see a broadening of this stigma to the
point where it came to apply to all
persons who suffered from schizophrenia
and there are great research uh studies
that actually come from uh feland in
link to sociologists here at Colombia
that show that even though Americans
have actually grown more accepting of
particular mental illnesses stigma
against depression obsessive compulsive
disorder anxiety have all gone down over
the last 50 years stigma against
schizophrenia particularly as being
violent has risen over this same time
period And I think this history tells us
tells us why so one after effect of this
period is stigma of against
schizophrenia as being violent a second
thing we see in in the aftermath of this
history um is a literature that's called
the misdiagnosis or overdiagnosis of
schizophrenia in minority populations
particularly black men a third area
which I can talk about in a bit if you
wish is the criminalization of mental
illness and this assumption that people
with schizophrenia are threats to the
state uh in a certain kind of way but
there's a flip to the story as well
which is that schizophrenia was also a
metaphor a term a linguistic usage that
was taken up within civil rights
discourse itself I have a few chapters
where I talk about how schizophrenia
became a term that Martin Luther King
used in seven or eight of his main
sermons and in a bunch of his writings
and for King schizophrenia was an
illness that actually wasn't an illness
what he said was there's schizophrenia
literally means split mind and he said
there's a split in our minds between
Good and Evil dark and light and what we
need to do is choose the path of
nonviolent resistance schizophrenia was
also a term that was taken up by leaders
of the Nation of Islam Black Power
movement Malcolm X was himself
misdiagnosed with schizophrenia in a CIA
file I talk about that in the book um
many of the leaders use schizophrenia
but what they said is if not an illness
of The Black Mind instead schizophrenia
is a response to the illness of white of
white racism that basically this is a
justifiable means of fighting back
against White Society and it's
interesting for me what I do is track
through that particular usage and show
how that didn't disappear and part of
the way I get to
that is to look at present day uses of
mental illness terms in rap and hipop
and popular cultural music so so toward
the end of the book I do a a kind of
mini research project where I look at
lyrics databases and first what I do is
look for terms like depression or
depressed across all American popular
music and what you find is that terms
like depression and depressed show up in
the lyrics of people like America sticks
Selen Dion Joanie Mitchell the Eagles
you know kind of what you might call
White cuning in a c a certain kind of
way I hate to overgeneralize but it's
very often assumed to be a particular
mood disorder but if you go into the
same databases and you type in the word
schizophrenic schizophrenia or
schizophrenic uh as I talk about in the
book and I list um references to over
200 rap or hip-hop artists who the
artists are actually calling them SK
self selves schizophrenic uh Tupac Isham
other artists and basically what they
say is yeah I'm schizophrenic and I'm
violent and I'm hostile and I'm a threat
to your to you or to other rappers or to
the police or to the state and you
better get out of my way and it's really
interesting to say why would this mental
illness term show up in Hip Hop right um
and on one hand which I think would be
wrong is to say Well they're taking
psychiatric usage in a way and saying
I'm just crazy or something like that
which is in part true but for me it's
actually saying this history why this
usage is actually coming from an earlier
tradition it's coming right out of um
the usage in black power in the 1960s
basically saying hostility is a response
to structural violence and I'm going to
assume this identity is a way of
fighting back and so it's interesting
that it remains a protest identity in in
this particular
Forum really one of the things I I
really try to do very consciously in the
book is to to track a particular
evolution of that process and part of
what I show is that even though we had
all these asylums in the 1930s and 40s
and 50s where we locked away all of
these people there was this um and often
for long periods of time but not always
there was this assumption that we were
kind of treating people in a certain
kind of way that there was a possible
recuperation or cure obviously didn't
happen for a lot of people
but um you know there was an investment
I mean people were being locked away but
they were also seen as responsibilities
particularly in schizophrenia of the
state and and part of what happens with
this definitional and racial change in
the way schizophrenia is understood in
the 60s is a feeling that these people
aren't
just docile dependents of the state
they're also threats to the state
particularly with schizophrenia you see
a lot of concern that these people could
escape and kill people or they could
threaten our political order and
particularly in the 1960s when
schizophrenia becomes linked to civil
rights protest it's also schizophrenia
could bring down the state in in a very
uh you know this has happened in other
countries so it's not surprising but we
don't often think about that in the
United States but I think part of why
schizophrenia got linked to civil rights
protest in the 60s was
because mainstream Society was coding
threats against
the smooth running of the state as
insanity and and treating it as such and
so as that happens you see the evolution
of a process in which people with
schizophrenia are increasingly feared uh
and our hospitals uh particularly the
kind of hospital that I look at in the
book be come to look more and more like
like prisons to the point where many of
them including the one I talk about
actually become prisons and that's
something that didn't just happen near
Detroit where I look but across the
country according to Human Rights Watch
for
example in the present day if you are a
person diagnosed with schizophrenia and
you are in a state institution your
chances are exponentially greater that
that institution is going to be prison
rather than a hospital um Bernard
harcour a law professor at the
University of Chicago talks about the
transformation from a hospital based
institution to a prison based
institution and it's something that
happened across the country and that
happened obviously for many reasons but
part of it is this transformation in
which prisons became our deao Mental
Hospitals and we saw mental illness as
in some way threatening not just to the
people who suffered from it but also to
us mainstream
Society right well I you know again I'm
a practicing psychiatrist and I think
that I really believe in the advances of
Psychiatry our diagnoses are more uh
precise uh they get more precise with
every volume of the diagnostic manual
our treatments slowly get better over
time um and I'm not adverse to saying
that there are biological bases to
mental illness I'm uh part of a
department that does a lot of fantastic
research in brain Imaging um scans other
kinds of genetic research that really
looks at mental illness seemingly below
the level of culture context race
ethnicity at the level of brain
structures that are seemingly the same
in all people and at the same time I
feel like there's a false divide almost
like you have to
vote is an illness biological or is it
social or socially constructed and and I
I don't like that divide very much
because I think that all definitions of
illness and maybe particularly all
definitions of psychiatric illness are
always are always both it doesn't have
to be one or the other mental illness is
a real thing it has real material
consequences for people who suffer from
it and at the same time even the most
biological finding reflects social uh
social context in very important ways
and so I think Psychiatry is better off
looking both at biology and at Social
context and really trying to think of
the relationship between those and I
think doctors and patients are better
off that way um we certainly know that
depression is an
illness all you have to do is watch an
anti-depressant advertisement on
television right now and think about why
might it be that a person might see an
ad like that what are the forces that
are leading them to go in and ask a
doctor in part um in part it might be
that that ad speaks to some symptoms
they're having that are chemical
symptoms but you many of these ads play
off of familiar cultural stereotypes
about gender or parenting or social
class other kinds of things and so I
think doctors need to be aware both that
depression as one example is an illness
that has a a chemical basis but also is
deeply embedded in cultural norms about
uh gender social class race um so that
would be one example there's great work
that's been done now on bipolar disorder
by Emily Martin here at NYU and looking
at the kind of cultural basis of of
bipolar disorder um obsess some
compulsive disorder after the show monk
for instance is something that there's a
lot of popular conversation about and so
I think again it's true for all Illness
but it's certainly true for psychiatric
illness that these illnesses often
reflect cultural norms in addition to
biological realities and really we have
to be fluent in in
both well again I I think that we're
we're making a mistake if we don't see
that there's a cultural basis to
many illnesses not just psychiatric ones
breast cancer would be one prevalent
example right now different kind of
cultures surrounding it if you don't
understand the cultural meaning of in
illness like that you're going to you're
going to miss the boat even if you're a
great scientist um so I don't think it's
the case that it's just psychiatric
disorders but we know from history that
when we get the ultimate you know cure
for a particular illness or nail it down
it stops being a psychiatric illness and
it's taken up by internal medicine or
you know we know oh it's it was just an
iron imbalance or it was a vitamin
deficiency or something like that that
in a way it's taken away from Psychiatry
and taken taken to medicine but um but I
think that uh you know if you look at
diagnostic rates and treatment rates in
psychiatric disorders it's it's even
with all the controversy about ssris
right now um the the the Improvement
rates are are reasonably good compared
to other Medical Specialties and so I
think it's it's always going to be a
negotiation about what's the best way to
understand psychiatric Illness but of
course the flip side of that is that
there is this Aura of it's something we
don't know in a certain kind of way and
so Psychiatry is always kind of fighting
against that and probably that's why we
had a move toward saying things are
solely biological in a certain kind of
way is to you know rightly move toward a
more scientific basis
terrific well I mean it's it's there are
really exciting things happening in
genetics and neurobiology right now and
really looking at the ways in which
different not just illnesses but social
conditions and social pressures can
actually lead to actual uh brain changes
um you know there was a lot of Promise
in the development of pharmaceuticals
particularly with the Advent of newer
generation of anti psychotics and anti-
um depressants and we know from history
that there's a kind of natural
trajectory of the way that these that
these
medications um come out and and are
accepted so initially we say these are
cures for everything under the sun uh
and there's this dramatic rise and then
we say wait a minute these don't work
for anything which I think is happening
with the SSRI anti-depressants right now
and then we kind of figure out a
moderated use of well they're good for
some conditions and and not for others
and so again as I say I think that
there's
a a give and take that's part of the
process and part of it is based in
science but I also think you know the
1990s were often called the decade of
the brain in Psychiatry where we didn't
need to worry about Freud or about
gender psychoanalysis context all these
things were in certain ways kind of
pitched out the window because we were
going to get the answer to everything
from brain scans and I think Psychiatry
itself has come to in a way like
medications a more moderated
understanding of the brain itself is
very important but you don't really know
anything about the brain unless you know
about social context expectations
stigmas other kinds of things and so
hopefully these findings will continue
to be understood in in Social context
